column2: But I know that when I first came here from Africa, King Charles was still hiding in the oak-tree--because I saw him.

column2: THE THIRD CHAPTER

column2: MORE MONEY TROUBLES
column3: MORE MONEY TROUBLES

column2: AND soon now the Doctor began to make money again; and his sister, Sarah, bought a new dress and was happy.
column3: AND soon now the Doctor began to make money again; and his sister, Sarah, bought a new dress and was happy.

column2: Some of the animals who came to see him were so sick that they had to stay at the Doctor's house for a week.
column3: Some of the animals who came to see him were so sick that they had to stay at the Doctor's house for a week.

column2: And when they were getting better they used to sit in chairs on the lawn.
column3: And when they were getting better they used to sit in chairs on the lawn.

column2: And often even after they got well, they did not want to go away--they liked the Doctor and his house so much.
column3: And often even after they got well, they did not want to go away-they liked the Doctor and his house so much.

column2: And he never had the heart to refuse them when they asked if they could stay with him.
column3: And he never had the heart to refuse them when they asked if they could stay with him.

column2: So in this way he went on getting more and more pets.
column3: So in this way he went on getting more and more pets.

column2: Once when he was sitting on his garden wall, smoking a pipe in the evening, an Italian organ-grinder came round with a monkey on a string. The Doctor saw at once that the monkey's collar was too tight and that he was dirty and unhappy.
column3: Once when he was sitting on his garden wall, smoking a pipe in the evening, an Italian organ grinder came round with a monkey on a string. The Doctor saw at once that the monkey's collar was too tight and that he was dirty and unhappy.

column2: So he took the monkey away from the Italian, gave the man a shilling and told him to go.
column3: So he took the monkey away from the Italian, gave the man a shilling and told him to go.

column2: The organ-grinder got awfully angry and said that he wanted to keep the monkey.
column3: The organ grinder got awfully angry and said that he wanted to keep the monkey.

column2: But the Doctor told him that if he didn't go away he would punch him on the nose.
column3: But the Doctor told him that if he didn't go away he would punch him on the nose.

column2: John Dolittle was a strong man, though he wasn't very tall.
column3: john Dolittle was a strong man, though he wasn't very tall.

column2: So the Italian went away saying rude things and the monkey stayed with Doctor Dolittle and had a good home.
column3: So the Italian went away saying rude things and the monkey stayed with Doctor Dolittle and had a good home.

column2: The other animals in the house called him "Chee-Chee"--which is a common word in monkey-language, meaning "ginger."
column3: The other animals in the house called him "Chee Chee"--which is a common word in monkey language, meaning "ginger."

column2: And another time, when the circus came to Puddleby, the crocodile who had a bad tooth-ache escaped at night and came into the Doctor's garden.
column3: And another time, when the circus came to Puddleby, the crocodile who had a bad tooth ache escaped at night and came into the Doctor's garden.

column2: The Doctor talked to him in crocodile-language and took him into the house and made his tooth better.
column3: The Doctor talked to him in crocodile language and took him into the house and made his tooth better.

column2: But when the crocodile saw what a nice house it was--with all the different places for the different kinds of animals--he too wanted to live with the Doctor.
column3: But when the crocodile saw what a nice house it was-with all the different places for the different kinds of animals-he too wanted to live with the Doctor.

column2: He asked couldn't he sleep in the fish-pond at the bottom of the garden, if he promised not to eat the fish.
column3: He asked couldn't he sleep in the fish pond at the bottom of the garden, if he promised not to eat the fish.

column2: When the circus-men came to take him back he got so wild and savage that he frightened them away.
column3: When the circus men came to take him back he got so wild and savage that he frightened them away.

column2: But to every one in the house he was always as gentle as a kitten.
column3: But to every one in the house he was always as gentle as a kitten.

column2: But now the old ladies grew afraid to send their lap-dogs to Doctor Dolittle because of the crocodile; and the farmers wouldn't believe that he would not eat the lambs and sick calves they brought to be cured.
column3: But now the old ladies grew afraid to send their lap dogs to Doctor Dolittle because of the crocodile; and the farmers wouldn't believe that he would not eat the lambs and sick calves they brought to be cured.

column2: So the Doctor went to the crocodile and told him he must go back to his circus.
column3: So the Doctor went to the crocodile and told him he must go back to his circus.

column2: But he wept such big tears, and begged so hard to be allowed to stay, that the Doctor hadn't the heart to turn him out.
column3: But he wept such big tears, and begged so hard to be allowed to stay, that the Doctor hadn't the heart to turn him out.

column2: So then the Doctor's sister came to him and said, "John, you must send that creature away.
column3: So then the Doctor's sister came to him and said, "john, you must send that creature away.

column2: Now the farmers and the old ladies are afraid to send their animals to you--just as we were beginning to be well off again.
column3: Now the farmers and the old ladies are afraid to send their animals to you-just as we were beginning to be well off again.

column2: Now we shall be ruined entirely.
column3: Now we shall be ruined entirely.

column2: This is the last straw.
column3: This is the last straw.

column2: I will no longer be housekeeper for you if you don't send away that alligator."
column3: I will no longer be housekeeper for you if you don't send away that alligator."

column2: It isn't an alligator, said the Doctor--"it's a crocodile."
column3: It isn't an alligator, said the Doctor-"it's a crocodile."

column2: I don't care what you call it, said his sister.

column2: I won't have it in the house."

column3: But he has promised me, the Doctor answered, "that he will not bite any one.

column2: He doesn't like the circus; and I haven't the money to send him back to Africa where he comes from.
column3: He doesn't like the circus; and I haven't the money to send him back to Africa where he comes from.

column2: He minds his own business and on the whole is very well behaved.
column3: He minds his own business and on the whole is very well behaved.

column2: Don't be so fussy."

column2: If you don't send him away this minute I'll--I'll go and get married!"

column2: It can't be helped." And he took down his hat and went out into the garden.
column3: It can't be helped." And he took down his hat and went out into the garden.

column2: So Sarah Dolittle packed up her things and went off; and the Doctor was left all alone with his animal family.
column3: So Sarah Dolittle packed up her things and went off; and the Doctor was left all alone with his animal family.

column2: And very soon he was poorer than he had ever been before.
column3: And very soon he was poorer than he had ever been before.

column2: With all these mouths to fill, and the house to look after, and no one to do the mending, and no money coming in to pay the butcher's bill, things began to look very difficult.
column3: With all these mouths to fill, and the house to look after, and no one to do the mending, and no money coming in to pay the butcher's bill, things began to look very difficult.

column2: But the Doctor didn't worry at all.
column3: But the Doctor didn't worry at all.

column2: Money is a nuisance, he used to say.
column3: Money is a nuisance, he used to say.

column2: We'd all be much better off if it had never been invented.	We'd all be much better off if it had never been invented.

column2: What does money matter, so long as we are happy?"
column3: What does money matter, so long as we are happy?"

column2: But soon the animals themselves began to get worried.
column3: But soon the animals themselves began to get worried.

column2: And one evening when the Doctor was asleep in his chair before the kitchen-fire they began talking it over among themselves in whispers.
column3: And one evening when the Doctor was asleep in his chair before the kitchen fire they began talking it over among themselves in whispers.

column2: And the owl, Too-Too, who was good at arithmetic, figured it out that there was only money enough left to last another week--if they each had one meal a day and no more.
column3: And the owl, Too Too, who was good at arithmetic, figured it out that there was only money enough left to last another week-if they each had one meal a day and no more.

column2: Then the parrot said, "I think we all ought to do the housework ourselves.
column3: Then the parrot said, "I think we all ought to do the housework ourselves.

column2: At least we can do that much.
column3: At least we can do that much.

column2: After all, it is for our sakes that the old man finds himself so lonely and so poor."
column3: After all, it is for our sakes that the old man finds himself so lonely and so poor."

column2: So it was agreed that the monkey, Chee-Chee, was to do the cooking and mending; the dog was to sweep the floors; the duck was to dust and make the beds; the owl, Too-Too, was to keep the accounts, and the pig was to do the gardening.
column3: So it was agreed that the monkey, Chee Chee, was to do the cooking and mending; the dog was to sweep the floors; the duck was to dust and make the beds; the owl, Too Too, was to keep the accounts, and the pig was to do the gardening.

column2: They made Polynesia, the parrot, housekeeper and laundress, because she was the oldest.
column3: They made Polynesia, the parrot, housekeeper and laundress, because she was the oldest.

column2: Of course at first they all found their new jobs very hard to do--all except Chee-Chee, who had hands, and could do things like a man.
column3: Of course at first they all found their new jobs very hard to do-all except Chee Chee, who had hands, and could do things like a man.

column2: But they soon got used to it; and they used to think it great fun to watch Jip, the dog, sweeping his tail over the floor with a rag tied onto it for a broom.
column3: But they soon got used to it; and they used to think it great fun to watch Jip, the dog, sweeping his tail over the floor with a rag tied onto it for a broom.

column2: After a little they got to do the work so well that the Doctor said that he had never had his house kept so tidy or so clean before.
column3: After a little they got to do the work so well that the Doctor said that he had never had his house kept so tidy or so clean before.

column2: In this way things went along all right for a while; but without money they found it very hard.
column3: In this way things went along all right for a while; but without money they found it very hard.

column2: Then the animals made a vegetable and flower stall outside the garden-gate and sold radishes and roses to the people that passed by along the road.
column3: Then the animals made a vegetable and flower stall outside the garden gate and sold radishes and roses to the people that passed by along the road.

column2: But still they didn't seem to make enough money to pay all the bills--and still the Doctor wouldn't worry.

column3: And there are plenty of vegetables left in the garden.

column2: But the snow came earlier than usual that year; and although the old lame horse hauled in plenty of wood from the forest outside the town, so they could have a big fire in the kitchen, most of the vegetables in the garden were gone, and the rest were covered with snow; and many of the animals were really hungry.
column3: But the snow came earlier than usual that year; and although the old lame horse hauled in plenty of wood from the forest outside the town, so they could have a big fire in the kitchen, most of the vegetables in the garden were gone, and the rest were covered with snow; and many of the animals were really hungry.
